title: Discounting in Strategy Logic
abstract:
Abstract
Discounting is an important dimension in multi-agent systems as long as we want to reason about strategies and time. It is a key aspect in economics as it captures the intuition that the far-away future is not as important as the near future.
Traditional verification techniques allow to check whether there is a winning strategy for a group of agents but they do not take into account the fact that satisfying a goal sooner is different from satisfying it after a long wait.
In this paper, we augment Strategy Logic with future discounting over a set of discounted functions ùíüùíü\mathcal{D}, denoted SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}]. We consider ‚Äúuntil‚Äù operators with discounting functions: the satisfaction value of a specification in SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}]¬†is a value in [0,1]01[0,1], where the longer it takes to fulfill requirements, the smaller the satisfaction value is. We motivate our approach with classical examples from Game Theory and study the complexity of model-checking SLdisc‚Äã[ùíü]superscriptSLdiscdelimited-[]ùíü\textnormal{{SL}}^{\text{disc}}[\mathcal{D}]-formulas.
